article:
John Blanchard observed the crowd making its way through Grand Central Station.
He was   looking for  
the girl with the rose whose heart he knew, but whose  _  he
didn't . His  _  in her began thirteen months ago in a Florida  _  where he often enjoyed the pleasures of reading books. Taking a book
out of the shelf he  _  himself curious, not about the words of the book,
but about the  _  penciled in the margin1s  . The comments written there   _  a thoughtful mind.
With time and   _  he discovered the name of the writer, Miss Hollis Maynell, and  _  her address. Over the next year and a month the two  _   to know each
other through the mail. Each letter was a seed falling on a fertile   heart that was eager for  _  . Romance   was in the air.
Now he was excited at the thought of their   _  meeting.
A beautiful young woman was coming towards him. Almost   _  , he started toward her,
entirely not 49 _ that she was not wearing a  _  . And then he saw
Hollis Maynell. She was walking almost directly behind the girl. A woman well
past 40, with gray hair , she was very fat and,  in fact  , very ugly. The girl
in the green suit had already walked by.
He felt very   _  , but still he said, "I'm Lieutenant John Blanchard, and you must be
Miss Maynell. I am so  _  you could meet me; may I take you to
dinner?"
A gentle smile   _  on the woman's face.
"I don't know what this is about, young man," she answered, "but that young lady in the green suit   _  me to wear this rose. She said it was some
kind of test!"
